metadata.unitName: TEST orange Forces Shape Earth's Surface

questions.question: Which layer of the Earth is composed of solid iron and nickel and remains solid despite extremely high temperatures?

answers.explanation: Immense pressure keeps the inner core solid even though it is extremely hot.
The outer core is liquid, not solid.
The mantle is made of semi-solid silicate rock.
The crust is the cool, rocky outer skin of Earth.

questions.question: Compared with oceanic crust, continental crust is generally:

answers.explanation: Continental crust averages 35–70 km thick and is less dense than oceanic crust.
This describes oceanic crust, not continental crust.
The two types of crust differ in thickness.
Continental crust is mostly granitic, not basaltic.

questions.question: What is the physical state of Earth’s outer core?

answers.explanation: The outer core is molten, not solid.
The outer core is a dense, convecting liquid layer of iron and nickel.
No part of the core is gaseous.
That description fits part of the mantle, not the outer core.

questions.question: List the four main layers of the Earth in order from the outside moving inward.

answers.content: Crust, Mantle, Outer core, Inner core

questions.question: Convection currents that help drive plate movement occur primarily in the:

answers.explanation: The crust is brittle and does not convect.
Slow convection in the mantle moves lithospheric plates.
Outer-core convection generates Earth’s magnetic field, not plate motion.
The inner core is solid and does not convect.

questions.question: Temperatures in Earth’s outer core are closest to:

answers.explanation: This is far cooler than core temperatures.
Still cooler than the outer core.
Scientific estimates place outer-core temperatures in this range.
This is hotter than current estimates.

questions.question: Draw and label a cross-section of the Earth showing the crust, mantle, outer core and inner core. • Use a different colour for each layer. • Write one sentence beside each layer describing its thickness or composition.

answers.content: Student diagram includes: labelled layers in correct order, distinct colours, and an accurate descriptive sentence for each.
answers.explanation: See rubric: 4 marks = all criteria met; 3 marks = one minor error; 2 marks = two criteria missing; 1 mark = diagram present but mostly inaccurate; 0 marks = no attempt.

questions.question: Explain why the outer core is liquid while the inner core is solid, even though both are mostly iron and nickel.

answers.content: The inner core is under greater pressure than the outer core; the immense pressure keeps it solid despite its high temperature, whereas the lower pressure in the outer core allows the metal to remain molten.

questions.question: Approximately what percentage of Earth’s volume is made up by the mantle?

answers.explanation: Too low.
Still low.
Closer, but not the accepted figure.
The mantle occupies roughly 84 % of Earth’s volume.

questions.question: Describe two ways scientists gather evidence about Earth’s internal structure.

answers.content: 1. Analysing the speed and behaviour of seismic waves generated by earthquakes. 2. Studying samples brought to the surface by volcanic eruptions and drilling projects (e.g., boreholes, xenoliths).

questions.question: What is the main cause of most earthquakes on Earth?

answers.content: The movement of tectonic plates along faults
answers.explanation: Stress builds up where tectonic plates meet; when it is suddenly released, the ground shakes and an earthquake occurs.

answers.content: The pull of the Moon’s gravity on Earth

questions.question: In the Mars-bar model used in class, which part of the chocolate bar represents Earth’s crust?

answers.content: The thin chocolate coating on the outside
answers.explanation: The hard chocolate layer models Earth’s rigid crust sitting on softer material beneath.

answers.content: The whole bar represents only the mantle

questions.question: Write a clear definition of the word “landscape”.

answers.content: A landscape is all the natural AND/OR built features you can see in a particular area of Earth’s surface, such as hills, rivers, roads or buildings.
answers.explanation: Students should recognise that a landscape includes any visible natural or human-made features in a given place.

questions.question: During the 2024 Noto Peninsula earthquake, which of the following changes was reported?

answers.content: Part of the coastline lifted out of the sea
answers.explanation: The quake forced sections of land upward, changing the shoreline.

answers.content: A new volcano formed on the peninsula

questions.question: Why does Australia experience comparatively few large earthquakes?

answers.content: It lies in the centre of a tectonic plate, far from most plate boundaries
answers.explanation: Plate boundaries are where most earthquakes occur, and Australia sits well inside the Indo-Australian Plate.

answers.content: It is too large for seismic waves to travel across
Its climate is generally hot and dry
It is protected by high mountains all around

questions.question: When the epicentre of a strong earthquake is under the ocean it can generate a _____.

answers.explanation: The sudden movement of the sea floor displaces huge volumes of water, creating a series of powerful waves called a tsunami.

questions.question:
Complete the cause-and-effect sentence using the causal connective ‘so’:
“The tectonic plates met, so Earth’s crust __________.”

answers.content: cracked and buckled / was pushed upward and broke / fractured and lifted (any phrasing that shows the crust was deformed)
answers.explanation: Students should show that the crust changed shape quickly as a result of the plates colliding.

questions.question: Give one reason why a country like Australia might provide emergency aid to another nation after an earthquake and tsunami.

answers.content: To help save lives and rebuild essential services because the affected country may not have enough resources after the disaster.
answers.explanation: Answers may mention humanitarian responsibility, international cooperation, or helping restore damaged landscapes and infrastructure.

questions.question: What is molten rock called AFTER it reaches Earth’s surface during a volcanic eruption?

answers.explanation: Magma is molten rock below Earth’s surface.
Once molten rock emerges from a volcano it is called lava.
Ash is the fine rock powder ejected during some eruptions.
Crust is Earth’s solid outer layer.

questions.question: In the classroom model, which reaction causes the “eruption” to bubble out of the jar?

answers.explanation: Vinegar (acid) reacts with baking soda (carbonate) to release carbon-dioxide gas, forcing liquid out like an eruption.

questions.question: Describe ONE constructive effect and ONE destructive effect that volcanic eruptions can have on Earth’s landscape.

answers.content: Example constructive: Lava flows cool and create new land or islands. Example destructive: Ash and lava can bury towns and forests.
answers.explanation: Constructive answers might mention new land, fertile soils, formation of islands. Destructive answers might include burying settlements, killing organisms, causing landslides or tsunamis.

questions.question: Use a causal connective to explain a knock-on effect of the fertile soil produced by volcanic ash.

answers.content: Because volcanic ash adds minerals to the ground, crops grow more vigorously, which attracts more farmers to the area.
answers.explanation: Student must include a connective such as 'because', 'therefore' or 'as a result' and link fertile soil to a subsequent effect (e.g. better crops, increased population, richer ecosystems).

questions.question: Mount Vesuvius erupted and buried the Roman city of Pompeii in which year?

answers.explanation: Historical records place the catastrophic eruption in 79 AD.

questions.question: Draw and label a cross-section of a volcano that includes the magma chamber, main vent, lava flow and ash cloud.

answers.content: Student diagram clearly labels the four required features and shows their correct relative positions.
answers.explanation: Full marks for correct labels and a coherent diagram. Partial marks may be awarded for 2–3 accurate labels.

questions.question: Which term describes the process of breaking rock into smaller pieces in the place where it is found?

answers.explanation: Weathering is the physical or chemical breakdown of rock in situ.
Erosion involves movement of weathered material.
Deposition is when eroded material is laid down elsewhere.
Melting changes solid rock to liquid magma, not the same as weathering.

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT identified as an agent of weathering in this lesson?

answers.explanation: Sunlight can heat surfaces, but wind, water and plants were the three agents discussed.

questions.question: In the sugar-cube shaking investigation, the shaking of the jar models the action of:

answers.content: Moving water tumbling rocks against each other
answers.explanation: Rivers and waves roll rocks so they bump and abrade, just like the cubes in the jar.

answers.content: Gravity pulling rocks downhill in a landslide

questions.question: Describe HOW moving water can weather a rock. Use cause-and-effect language in your answer.

answers.content: Flowing rivers, rain or waves carry sand and other particles that strike the rock again and again, so the surface is worn away and the rock becomes smoother and smaller over time.
answers.explanation: Answer should mention particles transported by water repeatedly hitting the rock, causing the surface to wear down.

questions.question: Give TWO causal connectives you could use in a paragraph to link cause and effect when writing about weathering.

answers.content: Any two of: because, so, therefore, as a result, due to, consequently.
answers.explanation: Students need to list any two correct causal connectives.

questions.question: Roots grow into small cracks in rocks and push the cracks wider as the roots thicken. Which agent of weathering is acting here?

answers.explanation: Growing roots are a biological (plant) agent of weathering.

questions.question: Create a labelled comic-style sketch that introduces your own weathering superhero made from any TWO agents (wind, water, plants). Show and label at least two ways your hero weathers rock.

answers.content: Teacher-scored drawing. Rubric: 4 marks – Two agents combined, clear labels, accurate explanation of two weathering actions, creative artwork.

questions.question: Explain the difference between weathering and erosion.

answers.content: Weathering breaks rock into smaller pieces where it is; erosion moves those pieces to a new place.
answers.explanation: Key distinction: weathering = breakdown in place; erosion = transport.

questions.question: Which term describes the movement of rocks, soil and sand from one place to another?

answers.explanation: Weathering is the breaking of rock into smaller pieces, not the movement of those pieces.
Erosion is the process that moves weathered material to a new location.
Deposition is the dropping or settling of the material after it has been moved.
Sedimentation is the build-up of material after deposition, not the movement itself.

questions.question: In the class investigation, what single variable was CHANGED to test the effect on erosion?

answers.explanation: The same amount of water was used for each trial to keep the test fair.
All trays contained the same damp sand.
Only the number of books under the tray was varied to create three different slopes.
Water temperature was not altered in this investigation.

questions.question: Explain WHY a steeper slope causes moving water to erode more sand.

answers.content: A steeper slope makes water flow faster. Faster-moving water has more force, so it can pick up and carry more sand particles away, causing greater erosion.

questions.question: Which tray in the experiment SHOULD have shown the LEAST amount of erosion?

answers.content: Tray resting flat on the table
answers.explanation: With no slope, the water flows slowly and has less energy to move sand.
This gentle slope produced more erosion than the flat tray.
This was the steepest slope and produced the most erosion.

answers.content: All trays should show the same erosion
answers.explanation: Changing the slope created different erosion results.

questions.question: To keep the investigation a FAIR TEST, which factor needed to stay the SAME for all three trays?

answers.content: Volume of water poured each time
answers.explanation: Using the same volume of water ensures that only slope affects erosion.

answers.content: Number of books under the tray
answers.explanation: That factor was intentionally changed to create different slopes.

answers.content: Height of the sand at the start
answers.explanation: All trays started with the same amount of sand, but this was not the focus variable.
Camera settings do not influence the scientific results.

questions.question: Name ONE other natural force (besides moving water) that can cause erosion.
Erosion usually happens AFTER which of the following processes?

answers.explanation: Sedimentation is a result of deposition, not a precursor to erosion.
Weathering breaks down rock; the pieces are then moved away by erosion.
Melting changes state of matter and is unrelated to the breakdown of rock.
Combustion is burning, not a geological surface process.

questions.question: Draw and label a diagram that shows how water flowing down the STEEPEST tray carried sand and where most of the sand was deposited. Include arrows for water flow and labels for areas of erosion and deposition.

answers.content: Diagram includes: (1) arrow(s) showing fast water flow down steep slope; (2) labelled ‘erosion’ area where sand is picked up; (3) labelled ‘deposition’ area at bottom or sides where sand piles up.
